posts.title: Introducing the Orbital Conservation Institute
posts.author: Jamie Harper
posts.excerpt: The Orbital Conservation Institute was founded with a singular mission: to preserve the orbital environment for future generations through scientific research, policy development, and international cooperation.
posts.content:
The Orbital Conservation Institute (OCI) emerges at a critical juncture in humanity's relationship with space. As we witness unprecedented growth in satellite deployments, space tourism, and orbital infrastructure, the need for dedicated conservation efforts has never been more urgent.

Our mission extends beyond traditional space policy. We are committed to developing innovative solutions for orbital debris mitigation, sustainable space traffic management, and the preservation of critical orbital regions. Through rigorous scientific research and collaborative international frameworks, we aim to ensure that space remains accessible and usable for generations to come.

The Institute operates on three core pillars: Research Excellence, Policy Innovation, and Global Cooperation. Our research teams are developing cutting-edge technologies for debris tracking and removal, while our policy experts work closely with international bodies to establish comprehensive regulatory frameworks.

One of our flagship initiatives is the Orbital Access and Sustainability Charter (OASC), a comprehensive framework designed to harmonize global space activities while maintaining environmental stewardship. This charter represents years of collaborative work with space agencies, commercial operators, and academic institutions worldwide.

As we embark on this crucial mission, we invite the global space community to join us in protecting our shared orbital heritage. The decisions we make today will determine whether future generations inherit a sustainable space environment or a cluttered, unusable orbital realm.
